measured_by: Reaction-time change across Cue–Target Interval (CTI) lengths
justification: “The analysis revealed a significant main effect of CTI … with longer CTIs yielding faster responses, indicating that, in general, participants actively prepared for the task during the CTI window.”

measured_by: RT / accuracy difference between switch trials and repetition trials in a Task-Switching paradigm
justification: The introduction notes that participants are “slower and less accurate when switching to a different task … compared to repeating a task, which is often referred to as the switch cost (Rogers & Monsell, 1995).”
“Stimulus type incongruency was defined as the number of images on display that afforded a different response … Higher levels of incongruency would give rise to stronger response conflict.”
“Task rule incongruency … could trigger their own responses that could either be compatible or incompatible … Similar to the stimulus type incongruency, task rule incongruency was 0 … 1 … and 2 …”

measured_by: Probability of task transformation inferred from CTI length
justification: “The length of CTI was predictive of how likely the task would be transformed (P(transform)) … participants had to actively update their predictions on transformation probability based on the time elapsed during CTI.”
